content: The "Loan Forgiveness for Certified Teachers Act of 2003" may be cited as the short title. The findings section is also included in the act. Congress finds that effective elementary and secondary schools need competent teachers and strong leadership. Local educational agencies would benefit from increasing the pool of qualified individuals for teacher recruitment. Talented professionals with subject matter knowledge outside of education may want to pursue teaching careers but lack certification. Loan forgiveness and other programs can encourage these professionals to become certified teachers, improving the pool of educators available to schools. Loan forgiveness and other programs can encourage professionals with subject matter knowledge outside of education to become certified teachers, improving the pool of educators available to schools. The Act aims to enhance the supply of qualified teachers by supporting individuals in meeting certification requirements. Loan forgiveness is provided for certified teachers. The Federal Family Education Loan Forgiveness program amends the Higher Education Act to provide loan forgiveness for full-time teachers who have worked for 5 consecutive years in qualifying schools. Teachers must teach relevant subjects and meet certification requirements. The Federal Family Education Loan Forgiveness program offers loan forgiveness to full-time teachers who have worked for 5 consecutive years in qualifying schools, demonstrating knowledge and teaching skills in relevant subjects. Teachers must also meet certification requirements and not be in default on their loans. The Federal Family Education Loan Forgiveness program requires teachers to meet specific standards outlined in the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965, including certification requirements and not being in default on their loans. The Federal Family Education Loan Forgiveness program sets specific loan repayment amounts for different types of borrowers and authorizes appropriations for fiscal years 2004 through 2006. Subsection (b)(2) borrowers will have their authority terminated on October 1, 2006. The Federal Family Education Loan Forgiveness program specifies loan repayment amounts for various borrowers and authorizes appropriations for fiscal years 2004 through 2006. Section 460 of the Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to include criteria for direct student loan cancellation for teachers who have worked full-time for 5 consecutive school years in qualifying schools. The Federal Family Education Loan Forgiveness program outlines criteria for loan forgiveness for teachers who have worked full-time for 5 consecutive school years in qualifying schools. Teachers must demonstrate knowledge and teaching skills in specific subjects and not be in default on their loans. The Federal Family Education Loan Forgiveness program requires teachers to meet specific standards outlined in the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965, work full-time for 5 consecutive years in qualifying schools, and not be in default on their loans. Authorization of Appropriations.--Such sums as may be necessary for fiscal years 2004 through 2006 are authorized to carry out loan repayment under this section for borrowers described in subsection (b)(1)(B). The authority for loan repayment for borrowers described in subsection (b)(1)(B) will terminate on October 1, 2006. The Secretary of Education will ensure that the implementation of these amendments does not interfere with existing student loan forgiveness provisions administered by the States. SEC. 5. GRANTS TO PROMOTE TEACHER CERTIFICATION AND LICENSING. Title II of the Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to include grants for institutions of higher education to encourage individuals to become certified or licensed teachers. An institution of higher education seeking a grant must submit an application to the Secretary with program details and assurances on fund usage for teacher preparation programs. The institution must submit a final report to the Secretary detailing the programs and results achieved with the grant funds. Preference is given to institutions with a plan to address the needs of underserved communities in their application for grants. An institution of higher education receiving a grant under this part can use the funds for programs to help individuals meet teacher certification requirements, including developing curricula, recruitment strategies, and other relevant activities. The funds cannot be used for construction purposes. The text chunk discusses the notification requirement for institutions receiving grants under a specific part, requiring them to inform state and local educational agencies, as well as students about the funded programs. Additionally, it mentions the authorization of appropriations. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal years 2004 through 2008 is provided in this section.
